Immediately on reading this inſulting anſwer, I was utterly beſide myſelf; and ſtill remember, as what happened yeſterday, the dreadful images which all at once came crowding into my imagination: on the one hand, the diſtreſs and indignation of my father, the diſhonour that I was fixing on my family, as well as on every one that knew me, and the dread of being broke with infamy; on the other hand, the briliant proſpect of that promotion which I might have obtained, by an honourable conduct in my poſt: nor did I afterwards recover the poſſeſſion of my underſtanding, but to think of perpetrating a new crime, that I might be delivered from that ignominy which my firſt would bring upon me. I was ready to go through with ſuch a deſperate reſolution, when I ſaw the very officer come into my apartment, whoſe reply had hurried me, as I have ſaid juſt now, into this ſtate of madneſs.

In the firſt emotion of my rage, I fell upon him like a fiend; but he diſarmed me very quickly; and while I but little thought of what was to enſue, embraced me, and began as follows. "I replied a little harſhly to your letter, as I meant, by ſuch an anſwer, that you ſhould ſee the horror of that ſituation into which your raſhneſs has pecipitated you; and I perceive what effect it has upon you. Now therefore that you repent, my property, my life, and every thing that I have, you may command, as you think proper."
"Here," continued he, and threw his purſe upon the table, "here is what will ſerve to pay your new recruits: and the remainder may ſupply you at the gaming-table, if you mean to return thither."
Return to the gaming-table! Never, never, anſwered I; and claſped him to my heart.

Since which, I have preciſely kept my word. From that day forward I determined to have done with all expenſive pleaſures, and apply my ſavings to the purpoſe of repaying what my generous friend had lent me. I employed my leiſure time in ſtudy. My attention to the ſervice recommended me to my ſuperiors; and to ſuch a happy
lution in the courſe of my affairs I am indebted for the honour of my preſent ſtation in the army.

This recital made ſo powerful an impreſſion on his officers, that every game of hazard ceaſed among them, and a noble emulation to arrive at uſeful knowledge quenched that low ambition of winning money which was their ruling paſſion before. Such was the good conſequence reſulting from their prudent colonel's leſſon.

div.head: THE PRODIGAL DOUBLY PUNISHED.
div.p: A Worthy private gentleman, obſerving with concern his only ſon upon the point of taking to a ſpendthrift way of living, let him do as he thought proper; and it was not long before the ſon had run himſelf behind hand to a great amount. I will pay whatever debt you may contract, ſaid the father to him, as my honour is much dearer to me than my money; but take notice of what follows: You love joyous living, and I love the poor. I have given away in charity a great deal leſs than I was uſed to do before I thought of your eſtabliſhment. I will think no longer of it; a libertine ſhould never marry; ſo indulge yourſelf as much as you think proper, but on this condition: I declare, that when, at any time, you ſpend beyond the money which I allow you to keep yourſelf as a gentleman, ſome hoſpital, or other charitable inſtitution, ſhall receive from me as much as you require to ſatisfy your debts; and I will begin this very day. Accordingly the money was that moment ordered to a certain charity; and thus the youth, on being doubly puniſhed for his prodigality, was quickly cured of a diſeaſe which otherwiſe would have inſured his ruin.

div.head: CHARACTERS.
div.p: The SCENE is in the garden of Mr. Fletcher; during the firſt act, in one part, after which it changes to another part.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: WHAT have you to do at Auguſtine's, then?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: I want to have a little converſation with him, Albert; and you know him likewiſe.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Yes, by ſight. You have not always been ſo intimate, I fancy, as you are at preſent.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Not before my father took a lodging here, adjoining his apartments. We ſee one another often now; and laſt night were together for an hour or two, at cards.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: I think, of late, you talk of nothing elſe but cards; and I have ſeen you frequently along with Rich and Vyſe, of whom I cannot ſay any good.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: You know them but too well; and would to heaven that I had never ſeen them!

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Is it ſo? But you may break off their acquaintance when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: That is not, at preſent, in my power. Would you betray me, if I told you ſomething?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: We have long been friends; and would you fear to truſt me, Jonathan?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: O my dear good Albert! they have made me miſerable, and engaged me to do things for which my father would renounce me if he knew them. I have not a moment's peace.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Alas! what are they?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Yeſterday they got me to go with them to a place where one Crib waited for them. We ſat down to play, and I loſt all I had.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: They cheated you, no doubt. But ſtill there is no great miſchief done; for never play again, and then your loſs will be a gain.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: But this is not the whole. As I had no more money, and ſtill wanted to win back my loſs, I ſtill played on, and in the end they got poſſeſſion of my watch, my coat and waiſtcoat buttons, buckles, and, in ſhort, of every thing that I had worth ſelling. I owe Crib a guinea likewiſe, and he will tell my father, if I cannot find means to pay him to-day.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: There is but one thing that you can do. Confeſs the whole directly to your father. I am ſure, he will pardon you on your repentance.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Never! never!

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: What will you do, then?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: I dare not tell you.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Let me know it.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: I communicated my diſtreſs to Rich and Vyſe, and they adviſed a ſcheme to extricate me.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: A fine ſcheme, no doubt!

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: It is not certainly the faireſt, as you will ſay; but what am I at liberty to do▪ I have already introduced them to young Auguſtine. He has money.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Well: you do not intend to rob him, ſurely?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Heaven forbid! They only mean to ſerve him juſt as Crib ſerved me; and then we are to ſhare the winnings, ſo that I may pay my debt.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: And ſo, becauſe you have been pillaged yourſelf, you would aſſiſt them to defraud your friend too? But how know you that Auguſtine will not win?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Oh! no: he plays quite fair.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: And you like a ſharper?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Like a ſharper?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: No; I am ſenſible that you play as fair as Auguſtine, and therefore you loſt. Now, as I hope you always mean to play ſo, how can you be ſure of winning?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: I do not know how it is; but they inform me that they have certain ways by which they are ſure of winning.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Ways! They are knaviſh tricks, and would you uſe them? I am not rich, and yet I would not mend my fortune by your certain ways. I am even ſorry that you have told me your intention.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: My dear Albert, have compaſſion on me, and I promiſe—

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Promiſe! What can bring me to aſſiſt in your deception?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: No; I mean to ſay, that if I am but ſo lucky as to pay this odious Crib, I will break off all connexion with him and his friends; and never touch a card again. If I ſhould break this promiſe, you ſhall be at liberty to tell my father every thing. (Albert ſhakes his head.) Yes, every thing. And then, it will not reſt with me to cheat: I cannot if I would, and Crib has taken that upon himſelf. I ſhall but play my cards: they have promiſed that I ſhall be no loſer, but divide the profit with them.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Well; I will make a party with you.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: I deſire no better, and will inſtantly invite young Auguſtine for the afternoon. His father is at preſent in the country, and will not come back perhaps theſe three weeks.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Quite convenient! But take notice, if yourſelf ſhould cheat him—

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Do not talk ſo. I wiſh I had not told youthe affair.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: And ſo do I. I ſhould not then be anſwerable for it.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Anſwerable?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: To my conſcience, ſurely. I can ſee a worthy youth on the point of being cheated.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: But you will not cheat him.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Jonathan, if you ſaw a thief pick even a ſtranger's pocket, ought you to keep ſilence?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Auguſtine will but loſe two, three, or poſſibly four guineas, and be cured of playing.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Juſt as you are cured. But here comes Auguſtine, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Good morrow to you both.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Good morrow, Auguſtine.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: What, you have not been down yet into the garden, when it is ſuch fine weather?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Mr. Auguſtine does not like to run about as you do, and can entertain himſelf in his apartment.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Yes; but I have been already walking in the garden, and even breakfaſted with Honoria and my father in the grove.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: (ſurprized.) Is he returned ſo ſoon? I fancy, you are not well pleaſed at that.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Not well pleaſed! when he has been three weeks away?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: I love my parents well enough; and yet, if they ſhould take it in their heads to travel, it would not vex me.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: And, for my part, I could wiſh my father never out of fight, he is ſo extremely kind!

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: And mine ſo harſh, I muſt not think of pleaſure when he is near me.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Who can tell what pleaſures you expect!

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: I thought you were in want of nothing on that head. Since we have lodged together, I have almoſt every day obſerved you at the door; and when I have met you in the garden, never could I ſee you under any thing appearing like reſtraint.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: No, no; I have always met you on days when my father dined abroad, and that is the only time that I have to uſe as I think proper; therefore I do turn it to account. But now your father is come home, I take it, we ſhall not ſee you quite ſo often in an evening?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Why not, Jonathan? He refuſes me no pleaſure that I can aſk. However, I muſt ſay, I find no company like his; and he, too, has frequently ſaid that he thinks my company and Honoria's quite delightful.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: What a charming father! So then he permits you to go out both when and where you like?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: He does, becauſe I always tell him where I am going.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: And becauſe he knows that you never go but where you tell him?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: What then do you do for entertainment, when you are both together?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: In the ſummer evenings, frequently we take a walk.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: In winter?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: We ſit down before the fire, and talk of fifty curious matters; or I ſtudy geography, and take a leſſon in the mathematics. Sometimes too, with Honoria and a friend or two, we act a little drama of ſome kind or other. You cannot think how that amuſes us!

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: But ſure ſuch different ſtudies are enough to crack your brain!

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: On the contrary, they come of courſe, as if they were an amuſement.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: A game at cards I ſhould ſuppoſe much more amuſing. Do you ever play?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Yes, truly; and my father frequently makes one.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: And do you play for money?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Doubtleſs; but a trifle, juſt enough to intereſt one in the game; and particularly, as by that, my father ſays, one learns to loſe with temper.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: That is quite right; one ought to huſband, as they ſay, one's purſe,

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Oh! do not imagine that I want money. I have more than I can uſe.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: How much?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: A crown a week.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: A good allowance, truly! And all that to purchaſe trifles?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Yes, ſuch trifles as my father would not like to have me trouble him about; and that, I muſt acknowledge, makes me much more careful.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: I believe ſo. One can hardly chuſe but know the worth of things, when one muſt pay for them one's ſelf.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p:
True, Albert. And beſides, one naturally ſaves in that caſe, as I myſelf have found it; ſo that what
with preſents and ſome other matters, I have now five guineas in my pocket, without reckoning ſilver.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Such a deal! And how can you employ it?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Have I nothing then to buy? However, I can diſpoſe of it otherwiſe. I pay to have our footman's daughter put to ſchool; and every Monday morning ſend a trifle to a writing-maſter that I had once, and who is now grown blind: theſe, both together, make up ſomething; and I keep the reſt for ordinary uſes, and among them, for play.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: At which you are tolerably lucky. You remember, you won half a crown of me the other night, at One-and-thirty.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: I was ſorry, as I always am, to win of friends.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Then you ſhall have an opportunity at night of loſing, if you think fit. Are you engaged?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: No; I ſhall ſtay at home. My father is to draw out a petition for a widow woman, who would get into an alms-houſe.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: That is well: and mine goes out at five. Come then to me, and I will endeavour to amuſe you. We ſhall have Rich, Vyſe, and Crib.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: I will run and aſk my father's leave. Shall you be here when I return?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: No, I muſt go and give them notice of the party; but your anſwer Mr. Albert will bring to me.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Will you go in with me, Mr. Albert? I am ſure, my father will be very glad to ſee you: he has often told me what a great eſteem he has conceived this long while for you.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: I am very happy in his partiality. The eſteem of ſuch a gentleman is highly honourable; but at preſent I am rather indiſpoſed, and ſhall remain, with your permiſſion, in the garden.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Do; a turn or two will ſettle you, and I ſhall not be abſent long.

I do not know what to do in this affair! Poor Jonathan is afflicted! I ſhould like to extricate him; but then to let the worthy Auguſtine be cheated! No, the accomplice is not better than the robber; and to favour roguery is juſt as bad as doing it. I will go therefore and tell the whole. But, ſoftly! here comes Honoria. Let me firſt of all do every thing in my power to aſſiſt her in preſerving Auguſtine from the danger, and yet not betray my friend.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: What, you here, Mr. Albert, and alone? I thought I ſaw my brother talking with you.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: He has juſt now left me.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: I ſhould wiſh him never to leave you, if his company were but agreeable to you: I ſhould not be uneaſy then.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: You do me honour, miſs; but ſurely Mr. Auguſtine is too ſenſible to give you any pain.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: I have no pain while he keeps company with ſuch as you: but ſhall I come directly to the point? I do not think any good of thoſe companions of Jonathan's; and he wants by all means to mix with them.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: I have not yet perceived that their company has hurt him.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: True; but my poor brother, I muſt ſay, is innocent, and ſomewhat credulous: he judges every one to be like himſelf. What would become of him, if thoſe whom he thinks his friends were what they ſhould not be? I have remarked, that you do not much approve of Jonathan's intimates.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: To ſay the truth, my dear young lady, I ſhould rather wiſh that Jonathan would be ſatisfied with Auguſtine's friendſhip. There is one advantage, notwithſtanding, that his father watches over him, as yours does over Auguſtine, and inſtructs him what to do.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: The miſchief often is remarked too late; it is eaſier to prevent than cure it.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: I am ſure, you love your brother tenderly, and therefore hear me; but tell nobody that I mentioned what I am going now to ſay. Young Jonathan has prevailed upon him, juſt before you entered, to make one with him and his three intimates. They mean to play, no doubt; but do your utmoſt to divert your brother from partaking with them. I deſigned to wait here for his anſwer, but do not think it proper that I ſhould carry it. I make no doubt but he will bring it preſently. Pray do not judge amiſs of me that I retire; and think of the advice which my duty, as a friend to Auguſtine, bade me give you.

As a friend! This looks a little ſerious! Ah, my poor dear brother! ſhould it chance that you, who are at preſent all the joy and conſolation of my father, were to change, and be the cauſe of his affliction for the time to come!

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: My father's friends are willing, I can ſee, to take the earlieſt opportunity of paying him their compliments on his arrival, juſt as if he had been abſent for a twelvemonth. I could hardly thruſt a word in.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: You had ſomething then of conſequence to tell him.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Of the greateſt conſequence to me. I want to paſs the evening with my friends.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: With Mr. Jonathan, no doubt?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: I thought ſo. You might eaſily have gueſſed, however, that ſuch a friend as Jonathan does not pleaſe me.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p:
Truly, Jonathan is greatly to be pitied, being ſo unfortunate as not to have a place in your
good graces! And what ſhould he be, to merit ſuch an honour?

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: He ſhould be—juſt ſuch a one as you are.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Do you mean to joke?

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: No: I am very ſerious, I aſſure you; and conſider you a very amiable young man without a fault, unleſs indeed it be the want of due politeneſs to your ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: And why ſo? becauſe that ſiſter is a little critic, and pretends to greater underſtanding than her brother.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: Truly, I had quite forgot to mention modeſty, when I was drawing up your panegyric.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: But what means this prating? and pray tell me, why theſe intimations with regard to Jonathan! Do you know him?

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: I would know him by his actions.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Are you always with him, to remark them?

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: I can gueſs them from the company that he keeps.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: I underſtand you perfectly: his company diſpleaſes you, becauſe I am one of his acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: Surely, brother, he muſt have acquaintances of longer ſtanding than yourſelf; and I ſpeak of them as I would of good for nothing fellows.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Good for nothing fellows?

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: Yes, that play, and practiſe each diſhonourable trick to win their adverſary's money, and then ſpend it more diſhonourably ſtill.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Oh! what two great crimes! they play when they are together; and they ſpend their winnings as they pleaſe. We do the ſame, I fancy. And beſides, you ſay, they play to win; but they have often loſt to me.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: Yes, yes; they have loſt their copper, and have won your ſilver.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Well, and if they have, the loſs was mine, not yours. But this is juſt like what my ſiſter is. She would be ſorry if ſhe could not vex me in my pleaſures, notwithſtanding I do every thing to heighten hers.

sp.speaker: Honoria,
sp.p:
(taking him by the hand.) No, brother; every pleaſure that you can have, is alſo mine; but for the world, I would not have your pleaſures hurt you, and
deprive me of the ſatisfaction which I receive from loving you.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: I know indeed that you love me; but am hurt to find you fancy me incapable to guide myſelf.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: And yet you would not be the firſt that—but here comes my father.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: My dear children, I have juſt now been enjoying a delightful ſatisfaction!

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: That of being viſited on your return by your acquaintance, I ſuppoſe you mean? But certainly your friends muſt cheriſh you, when we who are reſtrained by your authority, rejoice as much as they can do.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Yes, truly; for without you we can find no pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: And yet you muſt learn to do without me; ſince, according to the ordinary courſe of nature, I ſhall certainly go firſt.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: O ſir, would you afflict us at a time when we thought of nothing but rejoicing?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, you will live, and long we hope, for our advantage. But let us talk no more on ſuch a gloomy ſubject.—I have a little favour to requeſt.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Well, come, let us hear it.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Maſter Jonathan—you are acquainted with his father—Well, he has invited me to ſpend the evening with him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: You have a new acquaintance then. I am glad that you pick up ſuch good company ſo near you.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: You hear that? good company!

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: I think him ſo; I have already ſat down with him ſeveral times, and he has introduced me alſo to ſome friends of his.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: Good company, too, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Yes, for ſure I muſt know them better than you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: When I uſed the words good company, I meant diſcreet and well bred.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, extremely ſo.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: And how are you to know that they are ſuch, as you have only ſeen them once or twice?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: But have I not been hours together with them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: How did your acquaintance begin?

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: At play.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: And why not ſo? My father lets me play.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: It is true, for recreation, and for ſuch a ſum as being gained will not induce the immoderate love of money, or if loſt, not put one out of temper; and this likewiſe at a time when nothing can be done more profitable.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: But I thought, ſir, ſomething might be always done more profitable?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Yes, (I ſpeak of myſelf, for inſtance,) if I could but nail my thoughts continually to ſome book or other.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Honoria's remark is not amiſs. One may employ a leiſure evening better than at play, no doubt, if people would be always rational, or even innocently mirthful; but as ſcandal ſometimes will go round, or folly; in ſuch caſe, you know, I bid you play, and often take a part myſelf.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: And theſe I doubt not, brother, are the reaſons why you play?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: I do not ſee any right that you have to catechize me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: But why take offence at what ſhe ſays through friendſhip?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Rather, ſir, from a deſire to hurt me in your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Can you conceive ſuch notions of your ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Honoria,
sp.p: (with a tone of tenderneſs.) Brother!

sp.speaker: Auguſtine,
sp.p: (with the ſame tone.) Honoria, pardon me: I am in the wrong to tax you thus: but grant, however, your inſinuations unavoidably muſt hurt me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Her ſuſpicions may have ſome foundation that does not reflect upon you: we need not fear, I think, our diſpoſitions towards each other, ſo united as we are. (Honoria and Auguſtine take their father by the hand.)

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: O ſir, how good you are!

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: You lay by all a father's rights, and are our friend.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: If I were any other than your friend, I ſhould not be compleatly qualified to bring you up. I might perhaps connive at your neglecting outward ceremonies of reſpect; but not your failure in that confidence which I expect from your affection. You ſhould not have a ſecret that you would keep hid from me, as whenever you may chance to be in danger, my experience may preſerve you from it. Let me therefore aſk you, Honoria, what are the objections that you have formed againſt your brother's new acquaintances?

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: They are always taken up with cards.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Who told you ſo?

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: No matter from whom I have my information: the thing is, whether it be true?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: I have already told you what I think of playing: every thing depends upon the game that you play.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Oh! it needs no great attention: it is the game of one and thirty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: I confeſs, I do not approve it much.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Why not? There can be nothing in the world ſo innocent. Whoever is one and thirty, or the neareſt to it, wins.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: And do you know that it is what we call a game of chance?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Becauſe one has a chance to win or loſe? and muſt not this be ſaid of every game?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: With this material difference, that at one and thirty, chance alone decides; whereas, in many others, ſkill is to be ſhown. In ſhort, one wants but fingers, and no head for games of chance: and in my thought, ſuch games are utterly unworthy of a thinking man.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: They cannot even amuſe one.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Do not ſay ſo, dear ſiſter. There is a deal of pleaſure in expecting ſuch or ſuch a card as one may want.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Becauſe the love of money makes it ſo. And as this love of money operates very powerfully, it is a ſtrong temptation for ten thouſand rogues to follow gaming as a trade; and therefore unſuſpecting people generally are their dupes.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Do you believe ſo, ſir? but how?

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: I fancy, they muſt have ſome art or other, to arrange the pack in ſuch a way, as to obtain what cards they want.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Yes, that is in reality their ſecret. I cannot tell their method; but am certain, that they do employ ſome method, and have ſeen deplorable examples of it in my travels.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Oh! pray tell us what examples?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: With a deal of pleaſure. When at Spa, I was acquainted with a young gentleman, who loſt one night above twelve thouſand pounds, which was his all.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: His all! poor youth! and what did he do to live?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: He muſt have been beſide himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Deſpair obtained poſſeſſion of his features, when he ſaw his fortune thus irretrievably loſt. He looked ſo frightful, that I was forced to turn away my ſight; he gnaſhed his teeth, plucked up his hair by handfuls, and beat violently on his breaſt: he gaſped and panted like a dying man, and left the room quite mad.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: And pray, ſir, among thoſe who won his money, was there no one who would give it back, as I ſhould certainly have done?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: They kept their ſeats; and ſtill continued playing on: or if they turned off their attention from the cards, it was to look upon him with contempt.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: The wicked wretches!

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: But the worſt part of the ſtory is as follows: That this poor young man deſtroyed himſelf before the morning.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: Oh! how ſhocking!

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Dreadful! and from henceforth, ſir, I will never touch a card, I promiſe you. I'll run and tell this Jonathan.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Softly, ſoftly: you are always much too haſty in your reſolutions. One ſhould never wholly give a pleaſure up, becauſe, when carried to exceſs, it may be hurtful. I have often told you, that a game at cards, when friends are met together, is amuſing, innocent, and even uſeful.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: Uſeful, ſir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Yes, uſeful; as it teaches us to bear our fortune; and not to triumph when we win, or be dejected at our little loſſes.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Heaven be praiſed, I am not ſo fond of money as to hurt another by my inſults in good fortune; or to ſhew that I am hurt myſelf, by being vexed when I am unlucky; but to ſhun what poſſibly might happen, it will be better for me not to viſit either Jonathan or his friends.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: You would only prove your weakneſs, if this ſhould be your final reſolution: for at leaſt you have it in your power, when with them, to refrain from playing.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Oh, I know them: they would abſolutely make me play.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Well, play as much as they would have you, ſince by that means you will gain a better knowledge of them. But inſtead of going to this Jonathan, or his friends, invite them hither. You may alſo tell them that Honoria perhaps will make one.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: But, ſir—

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I have a reaſon.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: But ſuppoſe they win my money?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: You ſhall have it all from me again. And tell them, Auguſtine, that you expect a friend, whom you will prevail on to ſit down and play amongſt them.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: But you know, ſir, I expect no friend.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: When I inform you of a friend that you have at home, who will be with you, cannot you gueſs what friend I mean?

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: Sly! Why ſure you underſtand papa? he means himſelf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Yes, Auguſtine; for you recollect, juſt now you ſaid that I was your friend.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Oh yes; they will play indeed, if you are of the party!

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Therefore you ſhall not inform them who the friend is that you expect. As ſoon as I have finiſhed my petition, I will return and join you. I ſhall ſee what is proper to be done. 'Till then, play with them, and at any game they chuſe.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: So then you would have me run to Jonathan and his friends?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Yes, yes: and do not forget to deſire Albert's company. I ſhall be glad to ſee him. All his maſters praiſe him wonderfully, and you yourſelf have frequently been laviſh in his commendations.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: He merits every tittle of it.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: One word more, ſir; ſhall we meet here in the garden?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: As your pleaſe. The weather is ſo fine, you may ſtep here into the ſummer-houſe, it will hold all your company.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: I fear, ſir, your preſence will be much more neceſſary here than mine.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: You fear?

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; for I have told you, Maſter Albert was not long ſince with me. From ſome words which he dropped, I have reaſon to believe that my brother's company have laid a plot to cheat him of his money.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: All the better, if he finds himſelf their victim. I will hide myſelf behind the ſummer-houſe there, juſt by that partition, and hear every word of their diſcourſe. They will enter here, and cannot poſſibly diſcover me: but in the interim take you care; and if you ſee their roguery, ſeem as if you did not.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: I ſhall find it hard, ſir, to diſſemble. It will be painful to me, ſhould I ſee my brother prove the object of their ridicule, and fall a victim to his open nature.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: By himſelf alone can he be fully undeceived; and in that caſe I ſhall with leſs difficulty perſuade him to be attentive for the future in the choice of his connexions, and ſo cure him likewiſe of his love for gaming, which, I muſt acknowledge, he ſeems ready to adopt as a habit.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: How, ſir, can he have a thought of going thus to cards? He ought to know himſelf. He is ſo credulous, that every ſharper muſt ſuppoſe him proper for his purpoſe! and ſo warm, that at the firſt ill luck he falls into a paſſion!

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Yes, that is juſt his character. I did not think you ſo obſervant, Honoria.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: One ſhould be in truth obſervant of another's conduct, if one means to ſerve him. And—

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: A knock; it muſt be Jonathan's friends: they do not deſire to loſe a moment. I now leave you. I will go round about and gain my ſtation. (He goes out.)

sp.speaker: Honoria,
sp.p: (alone.) How I long to know the iſſue of all this! Alas! dear brother! who can tell but your future happineſs in life depends on the deciſion of the preſent afternoon.

div.head: SCENE XI.
div.stage: Honoria, Auguſtine, Jonathan, Albert, Rich, Vyſe, Crib.

sp.speaker: Jonathan,
sp.p: (to Honoria.) I was afraid, Miſs Honoria, as I mentioned to your brother, that our company might incommode you: but he would not—

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Incommode her! I am in hopes that ſhe will keep us company.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: With all my heart, if you think proper, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Vyſe,
sp.p: (with conſtraint.) You do us honour, madam.

sp.speaker: Crib,
sp.p: (whiſpering Jonathan.) This is quite unlucky! In politeneſs we muſt play whatever game ſhe likes. You ſhould not have conſented to come here.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Perhaps I ſhall be able, gentlemen, to introduce a friend of mine to your acquaintance likewiſe.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Shall you?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Yes, and not without a pocket full of gold.

sp.speaker: Jonathan,
sp.p: (aſide.) That is well.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: We will ſtay here in the garden, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: We cannot do better. We ſhall have the pleaſure of a charming walk.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Do you deſign to walk?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: What elſe?

sp.speaker: Vyſe.
sp.p: Why, play.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: But I do not underſtand your play; and if I did, I ſhall not wiſh to loſe my money.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: Wiſh to loſe it! juſt as if it were certain that you would loſe it!

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Sir, with you particularly. You are too ſkilful by a deal for me.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: If I ſhould win, I promiſe, I will return you every farthing.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: And I too.

sp.speaker: Rich and Vyſe.
sp.p: And we.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: You would make a fool of me. To loſe my money, and receive it back, or on the other hand, win yours, and keep it, is not what I do: ſo do not concern yourſelves on my account. I will ſee you play, or elſe walk up and down the garden hereabouts.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: My father, gentlemen, cannot have the honour to receive you, (Rich and his company ſeem rejoiced,) but has bid me entertain you. Auguſtine will get ready ſome refreſhments, and I will run and fetch the cards.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: That is needleſs: I have a pack about me.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: How! about you?

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: Yes: I ſtudy them.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: And have you fiſh too?

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: I ſhall beg you to get us them, unleſs we are to ſtake our money.

sp.speaker: Jonathan,
sp.p: (aſide to Crib.) You remember, I have no money?— (aloud.) No, no: we ſhall hardly know what we are about. And ſo, miſs, if you will be ſo kind—

sp.speaker: Monoria.
sp.p: Enough, I will bring the bag. Come, brother.

sp.speaker: Vyſe,
sp.p: (going into the ſummer-houſe with Jonathan, Rich, and Crib, while Albert walks about.) I am ſorry we are here.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: What matters, ſince the father is not here?

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: You ſhould not have conſented to the place of meeting, Jonathan.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Here, or in my room, what difference does that make?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Well then, when Auguſtine has loſt every thing, we will carry off his money, and go play where we think proper.

sp.speaker: Vyſe.
sp.p: We ſhall empty, very likely, the young lady's pocket alſo.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: Yes; that is what I look for: let us take care, however. We will put in our fiſh at two-pence each, for half a dozen deals or ſo; and when the game grows warm, and they have won a little, we will then make them double.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: You remember your promiſe, Crib?

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: Do not you be uneaſy. We know one another. All our loſs ſhall be in counters, and we will have no reckoning when the game is over. I will diſpoſe the cards in ſuch a way, that we muſt loſe at firſt, and that will draw them on.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: But, Crib, you know, you fleeced me quite the other day; and I have now but ſixpence in my pocket. How am I to pay my loſs?

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: Your loſs! we ſhall be ſure to win, if we attend to what we do.

sp.speaker: Vyſe.
sp.p: I ſhould be glad if Auguſtine's friend would come: he will be another pigeon that we ſhall pluck.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Yes, yes! I know of none ſo eaſy to be duped as theſe ſame bookiſh fellows.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: We had beſt begin, that they may find us buſy when they come. (He takes his cards out.) Stay; I will put them ſo that you may loſe. (He ſhuffles them.) Now you ſhall ſee. (He gives three cards to Jonathan, Rich, and Vyſe; lays down as many for himſelf, and then addreſſes Jonathan.) Do you ſtand?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: No: beg.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: Jonathan,
sp.p: (looking at the cards.) Out!

sp.speaker: Crib,
sp.p: (to Vyſe.) And you?

sp.speaker: Vyſe.
sp.p: One card, but not a high one.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: Much good may it do you!—there.

sp.speaker: Vyſe.
sp.p: Out too!

sp.speaker: Crib,
sp.p: (to Rich.) Now you are to be out. You beg, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: No; as Vyſe and Jonathan are both out, I ſtand.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: And ſo will I. How many are you?

sp.speaker: Vyſe.
sp.p: Twenty-five.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p:
And I juſt thirty. I have won: And yet I might have loſt by doing the reverſe of what I did; as you ſhall ſee the two firſt games that we play, when Auguſtine and
the lady comes, who having won, will then have no objection to play higher.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: But how can you be ſure of winning when you pleaſe?

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: You have already paid for your inſtruction, and I will let you know the ſecret. I tell every thing to friends, when I have pocketed their money. With my art you will win of others what you have loſt of me, and ſo be quits.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Well, let me know.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: You ſee, (ſhewing the cards,) the ten and court cards are a very little longer than the reſt, and all the ſmaller ones, as high as five, not reckoning in the aces, ſomewhat broader; by which means I can at pleaſure bring the picture cards, &c. to the top in ſhuffling, and the five, and thoſe below it, to the bottom. I contrive to give you two of thoſe on the top; and afterward, the other from the bottom: ſo that at the moſt you have but five and twenty, and will therefore generally beg. Well then, you have it from the top, and muſt infallibly be out.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: I underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: This is all my leſſon, and you have it upon eaſy terms; aſk Rich and Vyſe elſe, who ſo profitably follow my inſtructions. But I ſee the lady coming in, ſo puſh about the deal.

sp.speaker: Honoria,
sp.p: (putting down a box upon the table, with a pack of cards and fiſh and counters in it.) You do not loſe any time, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: I was but ſhowing Mr. Jonathan a new game.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: You will ſit down with us? We ſhall have that honour?

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: If I knew the game that you play—

sp.speaker: Vyſe.
sp.p: It is a very eaſy game. It is only One and thirty.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Had you never ſeen it played, you will know enough to beat us at it by the ſecond deal.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p:
I know a little of it. It would perhaps be better for me not to play with thoſe that know it ſo completely
as you gentlemen; however, if it gives you pleaſure—

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Oh yes, miſs, the greateſt in the world.

sp.speaker: Vyſe.
sp.p: And even ſhould you win, too, all our money.

sp.speaker: Honoria,
sp.p: (with a ſmile.) Yes, that is my intention.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: You will be ſcarce the richer for it in the end; we play but for a trifle.

sp.speaker: Jonathan,
sp.p: (with impatience.) Well! and what are we about? We paſs away the time in talking.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: We muſt wait for Maſter Auguſtine: it is but juſt that we ſhould amuſe him; we are his gueſts.

div.head: SCENE XIV.
div.stage: Jonathan, Rich, Vyſe, Crib, Honoria, Auguſtine.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Here, here I am. The ſervant will be with us very ſhortly. I have ordered ſome refreſhment.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Come, ſir, we are waiting for you.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Vyſe.
sp.p: Let us give out the fiſh.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: There are ſix of us: to every one two dozen, and ten counters; that is, ten dozen more.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: But how much every fiſh?

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: Juſt what the lady pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: Oh, it is rather as you like.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Our fiſh were two-pence each, when laſt we played together; five ſtaked every deal by each, and half a dozen the bon-ace.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: Well, be it ſo.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: Then here goes to begin. (Crib takes the cards and deals. The lady and her brother win by (rib's contrivance three times running.)

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: Hey! hey! if we go on in this way, I think, I ſhall ſoon fulfil my prophecy.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: While we play ſo low as two-pence, we ſhall never ruin one another.

sp.speaker: Vyſe.
sp.p: Well then, ſhall we make it four-pence?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Oh, with all my heart. I have ſo much money, you cannot break me eaſily. (He ſhakes his purſe, at which Crib and his companions look with pleaſure.)

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: And I can riſque as much, I fancy, as my brother.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: We muſt firſt then pay our debts, that we may have our full account of fiſh and counters.—Let me ſee, (after having counted.) I have loſt one counter, and ſix fiſh; that is, eighteen fiſh; and eighteen twice is ſix and thirty —juſt three ſhillings: there they are.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I have all my counters, but am maſter of no more than two poor fiſh; that is two and twenty loſt, or three and eight-pence. There.

sp.speaker: Vyſe.
sp.p: I am come off much the worſt. Two counters gone, and twice as many fiſh; which come to four and eight-pence.—I put down a crown, and take up fourpence.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Well, and you, Maſter Jonathan?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: I have loſt leaſt. No more than fifteen fiſh, or half a-crown. I will change a guinea, when we riſe, to pay it.

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: Good! So now I will ſee my winnings. One, two, three—Three counters, and three fiſh. That is ſix and ſix-pence juſt: of which I take four ſhillings, and the two and ſix-pence, Maſter Jonathan, you ſhall owe me.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: So that all the reſt is to pay my four and forty fiſh.—It is comical enough, however, that we ſhould be the only winners!

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Oh, I always loſe, for my part.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: So now the fiſh are four-pence?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Yes, that is ſettled.

sp.speaker: Crib.
sp.p: (ſhuffling the cards.) Come, I will deal.

div.head: SCENE THE LAST.
div.stage: Jonathan, Rich, Vyſe, Crib, Honoria, Auguſtine, Albert, (who came in a little while before,) Mr. Fletcher.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher,
sp.p: (to Jonathan and his friends, who ſeem confounded.) Pray do not diſturb yourſelves.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Sit down: my father does not come to interrupt us, I informed you that I might have a friend to introduce, and he will play with us. Won't you, ſir?

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: O yes: pray play; we ſhall be very glad to get your money, and theſe gentlemen, I know, will like to ſhare it too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p:
With all my heart. So every one fit down. (To Jonathan and his friends, who ſeem quite overwhelmed.)
But what is the matter, gentlemen? Are you afraid to play with me? I can aſſure you, I am no ſharper. (They ſit down at laſt.) You (to Crib) were dealing when I entered; ſo continue pray; but firſt let us ſee, have you a pack complete? (Crib wants to drop the cards, but Mr. Fletcher ſecures, and looks them over.) It is droll enough to have the court-cards all together thus! but, Honoria, why not give us cleaner cards? Pray hand me over thoſe—

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: It was not my fault, ſir, as this gentleman (pointing to Crib) had brought them in his pocket; and the play was going on when I came in with ours.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher,
sp.p: (to Albert.) What, you here, Maſter Albert! I am very glad to ſee you; but pray, do not you play?

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: I would rather be a looker on: you know I have nothing, ſir, to throw away.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: You are in the right to think ſo, and your prudence merits praiſe. (To Crib.) But come, ſir; here are better cards, (Crib takes them with a trembling band,) at leaſt a little cleaner: what is your game? Pray tell me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: And for what?

sp.speaker: Honoria.
sp.p: No more than four-pence a fiſh. I have won all this! four ſhillings; and two and ſix-pence owing me by Mr. Jonathan, who wants change.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher,
sp.p: (aſide.) Wants change! I ſmell a rat! (to Honoria.) So much as four-pence! that is a little too much; but no matter, if we have all of us enough to pay our loſings. So let us ſee your money. Mr. Jonathan, I begin with you; (Jonathan is confuſed.) What ails you? Are you taken ill?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Ye-e-es, ſir—Let me—

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: What is all this? one ſtammers, and the other ſeems confounded! (to Crib.) You, ſir, too, are diſconcerted?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: What is the matter with them?

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: It is high time that I ſhould explain the reaſon of this ſtrange behaviour. Auguſtine, you obſerve the effects of a guilty conſcience. Happily they are not yet ſo totally abandoned as to hide their villainy beneath a brazen front, and bully in their own defence.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: What ſay you, ſir? Sure you are miſtaken: It is my ſiſter, as ſhe told you, and myſelf, that are the only winners.

sp.speaker: Crib,
sp.p: (taking courage.) Have we failed to pay our loſings, every one, but Maſter Jonathan?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: No: but why? becauſe you have cheated me already out of all my money.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: I was right in thinking that they would unmaſk themſelves: And, Auguſtine, you may ſee what villains you have choſen for your companions.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Oh, I cannot think ſo, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Well then, Mr. Jonathan, do you ſpeak; you ſeem leaſt hardened. Tell me, was there not a plot among you to defraud my children?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Yes indeed, ſir; but for my part, I aſſure you, I was forced into it. All my wiſh was to get back a part of what I had loſt before. If you but knew how much this wicked fellow has ſqueezed from me, for the other two are nothing to him, you would ſay that he ſhould be ſent to priſon.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: You have well deſerved your loſs, by mixing with ſuch company: but tell me how much you have loſt?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Two guineas, and a few odd ſhillings with them all together; and my watch, coat buttons, buckles, and a guinea more in money afterwards, in private with the talleſt: but the guinea I ſtill owe him; and he threatened, if I did not prevail on Maſter Auguſtine to fit down and play this evening, that he would tell my father.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: This, ſir, I can ſay in Jonathan's favour, that he gave me juſt the ſame account this morning, and was grieved at what he thought himſelf compelled to do. The grand criminal is Crib, the talleſt; the two others in compariſon—

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: I comprehend what you would ſay; and therefore, (to Rich and Vyſe,) little raſcals, get you gone this inſtant. Perhaps it is not as yet too late that I ſhould think of reſcuing you from infamy; and therefore I will inform your parents of your conduct.

sp.speaker: Rich and Vyſe,
sp.p: (dropping on their knees.) Pardon us this once, ſir, we beſeech you; and we will never come within your doors again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: No; I ſhall take care that you never do; but then it is not enough that my children ſhould be ſafe in future from your roguery, I owe the ſame good ſervice to all fathers. What perverſity! at ſuch an age not only to be gamblers, but vile cheats! the hatefulleſt of human beings! However, out of pity to your youth, and from the hope which I have of your amendment, I will do no more than tell your parents; but if ever I am told that you ſtill continue your deteſtable employment, I will make known your infamy to every one about us. So be gone, and never let me ſee you here again. Be gone, I ſay. (Rich and Vyſe withdraw in ſilence and confuſion.) And you, ſir, is it true that you have got theſe things from Jonathan?

sp.speaker: Crib,
sp.p: (with heſitation.) Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: You have cheated him, but that is no matter. Jonathan loſt them, and has merited his fortune. We will put a value on them.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: I could wiſh, indeed, that I had ſufficient to redeem my loſs.

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: O ſir, if all that I have in my pocket be ſufficient, Jonathan may command it. I have full five guineas, take them for the ſervice of my friend.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Auguſtine, this is very generous.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: What, to me ſuch friendſhip!

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: We are neighbours both, and you may pay me weekly, or in any way you pleaſe. (Crib gives Jonathan his things.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher,
sp.p: (to Jonathan.) Is every thing returned you?

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Yes, ſir; and I am ſaved by your generoſity and Auguſtine's from the reſentment of my father. Oh, I will never riſque his gifts again in ſuch a manner.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher,
sp.p: (offering Crib the money.) Here is the value of your theft, for ſuch it muſt be called; and you ſhall have it to ſubſiſt upon in priſon till you are called to an •• er for your crime, as poſſibly you may not have the means without it. Nay, expect not by ſolicitation to divert the rigour of my juſtice. Your ſeduction of two youths, your felony upon the property of this young man, and your attempt to make him inſtrumental in the robbery of another, well deſerve that rigour. This muſt be your ſentence; ſo withdraw a little for the preſent. (Crib withdraws, and weeps for very rage)

sp.speaker: Jonathan,
sp.p: (falling on his knees to Mr. Fletcher.) O dear Sir! from what a gulph of ruin you preſerve me! And without you what would have been my evil fortune, when thruſt out from home, and perhaps ſtigmatized in public for my vices? I am then indebted to your pity for my reputation, my repoſe, and my exiſtence. (He riſes and embraces Auguſtine.) And my generous Auguſtine, you whom I was going to—

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Never think more of it; I do not; and for the time to come be happy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: Maſter Albert's teſtimony of your grief at being forced into this plot, alleviates your offence; and therefore you may ſtill continue to viſit my ſon; but after what he has juſt done in your behalf, I ſhall account you the moſt profligate of youths, unleſs you ſtudy to deſerve his friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Jonathan.
sp.p: Oh, I will do ſo. Rely upon me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: And as for you, dear Albert, I have reaſon to be charmed with what ſo many tongues have told me of your modeſty and virtue. By your laudable example, you may very much contribute to the happineſs of Auguſtine.—I requeſt you to be often with him; and if I can ſhew my gratitude by being ſerviceable to your happineſs, I ſhall promote it with as much affection as your parents would do.

sp.speaker: Albert.
sp.p: Your eſteem, dear ſir, is happineſs ſufficient for me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: You obſerve, my dear children, the unhappy conſequences that reſult from gaming?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Yes, ſir, and ſhall ſhudder all my life at the idea of them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Fletcher.
sp.p: You obſerve too, Auguſtine, with what care and circumſpection one ſhould chuſe a friend?

sp.speaker: Auguſtine.
sp.p: Yes, that too, ſir; and am convinced how happy it is for me to have a friend, as I have ſaid already, in my father.

div.head: THE MONKEY.
div.p: FRANCIS, and his play-mate Lorenzo, were at the window. As it chanced, they heard a pipe and tabor. Looking up the ſtreet, they ſaw a bear approaching ſternly, and a man conducting him by a chain to which the creature was faſtened at the other end. I ſhould be afraid, ſaid Lozenzo, to ſtand too near that animal; for do but liſten, Francis: Did you ever hear ſuch growling? I ſhould quake if I were by him. Oh, he could not hurt you, anſwered Francis; you may ſee, he has a muzzle to prevent his biting.

They were talking thus, when Bruin was come exactly oppoſite their window, in his progreſs down the ſtreet. Two monkies now took up the little gentlemen's attention. One was light and nimble, but the other not ſo active. Both were jumping to and fro on Bruin's back, who ſuffered them to play their tricks as if he did not care about it. They had fruit in plenty thrown them by the mob, which they caught in their paws as ſoon as it was flung to them, and ſwallowed almoſt inſtantly. But what delighted them particularly, were the nuts which the people threw them. Seated on their breech, and holding them between their two fore-paws, they broke the ſhells, and picked the kernels out with ſomething of an air.

It chanced that a very large one came among the reſt. The heavy monkey raiſed himſelf upon his long hind-legs to get it; but the little one darting forward, ſeized it in the air before it could have time to reach him. Cheated of his prey in this manner by the little one, he gnaſhed his teeth with rage. His front grew wrinkled, and his eyes flaſhed fire: he thruſt his claws out, fell upon the little one, and ſeemed upon the point of tearing him to bits. The bear found it very difficult to ſave him.

Do you ſee, ſaid Francis to his little friend, how frightful that ſame monkey is become ſince firſt he fell into a rage, and how he ſhews his teeth? Oh no, I ſhould not like to be within his reach! How terrible! I ſhould be ſcared to death!

Indeed? ſaid Lorenzo. Well then, can you imagine it; but yeſterday, when you were in a paſſion, you were like
him. Look ye, you had all his wrinkles; you even grinned as he does now; your eyes ſhewed what a paſſion you were in, and like the monkey, you ſeemed ready to devour poor little Harry, who had notwithſtanding done you no great harm. I only wiſhed that I could have got a looking-glaſs. Your face was in reality ſo ugly, it would have frightened you.

Indeed! ſaid Francis. Is it poſſible that I reſembled ſuch an odious beaſt? I could not but have been extremely frightful if I did, and muſt endeavour for the future to be never in a paſſion. When I find myſelf growing angry, I will then bethink me of the monkey, recollect the malice in his countenance, and that will make me ſhudder at the thought of being like him. Do you too, my good friend Lorenzo, if I forget this reſolution, like a friend remind me of it.

Lorenzo aſſured him that he would do ſo, and was faithful to his promiſe. Francis by degrees got rid entirely of his wrathful habit, or was very rarely in a paſſion. He enjoyed the greater happineſs, and his indulgent parents were not leſs tranſported at his reformation.

div.head: THE ALPS.
div.p: THE ſun was riſing in the heavens. The dew drops which are ſeen on every leaf ſo early in the morning, glittered with the colours of the rainbow; and the ſhadows of the trees were ſhortening on the ground, when Damon, holding his ſon, a grown-up lad, by the hand, came out, and ſat down on his garden terrace, to enjoy the freſhneſs of the morning.

Deareſt father, ſaid the ſon, pray wake me always at this hour; for I am charmed with contemplating ſuch a ſcene as I now ſee all round me! How delightful the whole proſpect! But perhaps it would be more ſo, were it not confined by younder mountains, which lift up their ſnowy tops ſo high that any one would ſuppoſe them to prop the clouds above them.

I do not think as you do, ſaid the father. Thoſe ſame mountains leave us ſpace enough, and that made up of
fields and meadows, to contemplate; and by thus conſining, as you ſay, the proſpect, help to vary it; and more particularly ſo at evening, when the ſun ſtill tips them with a thouſand ſtreaks of gold, even after the whole level plain is dark.
When we ſhall once have viſited thoſe mountains, and conſidered its inhabitants, you will be pleaſed with contemplating on them, I am certain, ſince they cannot but ſuggeſt agreeable ſenſations.
How can men, ſaid the youth, be fond of living on ſuch mountains, covered as they are with ſnow?

They do not live there, ſaid Damon; you will ſeek in vain to find inhabitants upon the heights: it is at the bottom of the mountains that they are ſituated. There are charming vallies ſtretched among them; but before the traveller can obtain them, he diſcerns no proſpect ſave that of barren rocks. This proſpect being paſſed, he comes to wide extended carpets of the greeneſt ſod; he breathes an air embalmed on all ſides by ten thouſand odoriferous flowers that grow there; and his ear is pleaſingly affected by the murmurs of as many ſtreams deſcending from the ſummit of the hills. The ſun, by ſhining on them with his noon day radiance, makes them put on the appearance of the b • ighteſt ſilver. And amongſt them, ſome, precipitated from a rock, re-echo when they reach the bottom, and there riſe in clouds, as one may ſay, of duſt, that yield a trembling kind of light. Their paſſage is diſtinguiſhed by a multitude of charming flowers which bloſſom on the margin; and the flowers, whoſe ſtalks wave to and fro, obedient to the breeze that agitates them, and the waters that flow in among them, heighten the delightful proſpect.

Spring is very late, and harveſt very early, in this region; whence it happens that the ground brings forth no other ſort of grain than what is ſowed ſome little while before the ſummer, and grows ripe betimes in autumn: hence, too, it comes that the fields are ſhaded by no other trees than thoſe producing cherries, plums, and other early fruit. Here and there the traveller meets with • am • ets; and the houſes being made of wood, are ſo much blackened by the ſun, as to afford a very ſtriking contraſt with the ſmiling verdure of the little orchards that ſurround them.

In thoſe hamlets live many innocent and happy families, which for the ſpace of five or ſix long months are almoſt buried under ſnow. As long as that ſad ſeaſon laſts, they take the greateſt care imaginable of their little flocks; at times they viſit one another, ſpin the flax which they have gathered before hand, and make different articles of furniture in wood, which they either uſe themſelves, or are ſure to fell for money to their neighbours.

As ſoon towards ſummer as the ſun has melted that vaſt heap of ſnow which covered all their fields and habitations, and the river that flows through their vallies has completely carried off the water with which their lands were overflowed, all the men begin to cultivate their fields or meadows, and the women labour in their gardens. During ſummer, the induſtrious father of his family repairs to other diſtricts with the produce of his labours, and brings back, in barter for them, thoſe conveniencies of life which are not to be had for money even in his hamlet.

Many travel upon mules, and croſs their craggy hills along ſuch paths as have been cut through rocks, and thoſe, too, over frightful precipices. They tranſport to very diſtant parts the honey which they have ſtored in autumn, which is univerſally acknowledged to be excellent. They likewiſe traffic in the ſkins of goats, which they entrap while climbing up the rocks, or find among them dead. Another article of merchandize for which they are diſtinguiſhed, is the dormouſe. This animal, benumbed by the exceſſive cold, retains in holes and cavities, which ſhe digs for herſelf to ſerve by way of habitation, and in which ſhe lies rolled up almoſt like a ball and on a bed of hay, that heat and life which, with returning ſpring, the ſun expands; and a fourth great object of their commerce is the cryſtal, which they contrive to quarry in the gaps or chaſms of their higheſt rocks. And many, on the other hand, are guides to foreigners who have the curioſity to travel over, and inſpect their frozen mountains.

I myſelf have been upon them, like many others, guided in my way by one of thoſe good men.—I call them good, in oppoſition to the multitudes that live in towns and civilized ſociety.—But yet they have loſt a great deal of their natural ſimplicity by frequent converſe with ſuch
foreigners as have employed them for guides. I admired the people, and their way of living; therefore, having ſatisfied my curioſity upon the mountains, I determined to remain among them ſome few days, that I might gain a better knowledge of their manners.

I muſt let you know what converſation I heard paſs between the wife and child of my conductor while I lived among them. I was ſitting on the graſs, beneath a pinetree: Julian, my conductor, had that day ſet out before the dawn, to guide two Engliſh gentlemen who came on the preceding evening to inſpect the mountains. It was ſtill broad day-light, but the ſun was rapidly deſcending towards the weſt. The mother aſcended upon a riſing ground; the ſon came after her. They fixed their eyes upon the icy maſſes which advanced their cloggy cliffs on the other ſide of the valley, and the wife began as follows:

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: I am looking to no purpoſe. I diſcover nothing. I do not ſee him yet.

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: Let us go to yonder rock before us, ſhaded by thoſe trees, and we ſhall ſee much better thence. There we ſhall be able to diſcern more plainly all that quarter of the mountain where my father, I ſuppoſe, muſt be.

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: Well, we are now got to it; notwithſtanding which, I can diſtinguiſh nothing more than from the ſpot that we have left. It is all loſt labour: he does not appear. And yet the ſun is nearly ſetting, and the day will ſoon cloſe in.

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: O! mother, we ſhall yet have two full hours of day-light.

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: And perhaps he may be four or five leagues diſtant. Who can tell exactly where he is? I wiſh he would give over wandering thus among the mountains. Never does he ſet out on his journies, but I tremble leſt unfortunately he ſhould not return alive: or elſe come back with broken limbs by falling down upon the ice, or while he ſcales the rocks.

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: I need not tell you that he has promiſed to drive this trade no longer, when the profits which he has made ſhall be enough to buy the little field between our cottage and the Arva.—We ſhall then live comfortably, with our flock, our honey, fruits, and field of barley.

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: Ah! dear ſon, I ſhould much rather wiſh to live in leſs abundance, ſo that I might only have more peace of mind. The happy days which we are to have when he has obtained this field, will have been bought too dearly, at the price of that diſtreſs and trouble which theſe his journies coſt. But do not I ſee him? No, not yet. If he ſhould be obliged to ſtay all night upon the ice!— If it—but you have got, I ſee, that ſpying-glaſs which a traveller lately left behind him in our hut, and that brings objects fifty furlongs off as near as if they were but ten. Look therefore if there is nothing to be ſeen. You know the uſe of it extremely well; but I, for my part, not at all.

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: I will reſt the end of it on this old trunk. I think, I ſee—yes, mother—ſomething, and it moves.— It is he, I verily believe!—Yes, yes, it is he indeed!— He is walking on the broken flakes of ice that lie near yon big rock, and which laſt month, you know, were ſeparated from it.

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: Let me have the ſpying-glaſs. Quick! quick! perhaps, too, I may ſee him.—I muſt ſhut one eye, you ſay?—I have;—but I diſtinguiſh nothing. Every thing is black.—Stay, ſtay. O now I ſee the rock!—and likewiſe men! and Julian is among them! But I have loſt them now: they are out of ſight: I cannot recover them again. Hold you the glaſs; I ſhall perhaps diſcern them with my naked eye.—Yes, yes, I ſee them. They are coming on, and in the middle of the valley. Julian, I can ſee, comes firſt.

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: They ſtop: my father ſticks his pole into the ice before him, and prepares to take a ſpring. There, there! he is up, and down again. No doubt but there was one of thoſe large gaps before him in the ice, of which he has ſo often told us. What can cauſe them?

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p:
I do not know exactly; but have heard that when the ice below is melted, that above it, having no ſupport, gives way, and opens with a noiſe which one may hear a great way off. You have obſerved the great round table in our curate's kitchen? Well, the leg which ſupported it in the middle was much higher than the others, and one day the ſides had many heavy things laid on them. Unexpectedly it ſplit exactly in the middle, and the crack grew wider, till the ſides could reſt upon
the ſhorter legs. And now I ſuppoſe theſe gaps are ſo occaſioned likewiſe. But look once again, and ſee what they are doing. They ſeem ſtanding ſtill. The gap ſure does not prevent them from advancing?

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: I can ſee their countenances very plainly. They ſeem aſking one another what they ought to do. Ah! now my father takes a ſecond ſpring; and now he is got ſafe over one more gap.

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I ſee him too. What raſhneſs! He might ſlip in ſpringing, or when over; or he might not poſſibly ſpring far enough, and drop into the gap. He does not take a ſingle ſtep but what he knows, as well as I do, makes my heart ſink within me. He ſhould think that it is not impoſſible but I may ſee him; he ſhould argue within himſelf, and ſay, My wife does ſee me, and my danger frights her.

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: He is very far, perhaps, from gueſſing what we are about now.

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: He knows that, while he is abſent on this dangerous buſineſs, I ſend forth my eyes to ſeek him. Would to heaven I could but ſhut them.

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: Yes, let us do ſo, mother. Let us put our hands before them, and not look again till he has cleared the valley, and is ſafe.

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: I cannot. I had rather tremble every moment for his ſafety, than loſe ſight of him, though for a moment only. But where is he? I can ſee him now no longer.

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: Nor I either.—They have diſappeared. Ah, mother!

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p:
My poor child! embrace me. We are now left to ourſelves, and I have nothing in the world to comfort me but you. Yes, they have diſappeared indeed; and in a moment too! I did but turn away my eyes to fix them upon you, and in that inſtant they are vaniſhed! An abyſs perhaps has opened under them as they were going on: perhaps they may be toſſing in it, not yet dead, but making unavailing efforts to get out, and calling for aſſiſtance with a voice which no one, to their coſt, is nigh enough to hear. I will haſten to the ſpot: come, follow me, my child! My knees knock one againſt another, and will hardly bear my body up; but I ſhall ſoon find ſtrength ſufficient to go forward. Come; but ſtay a little!
—Do not you, dear child, ſee ſomething there in motion? There, juſt where I point to; at the bottom of you rock?

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I think I do.—It is one of them. —It is one of them, indeed; and now I can diſcern the other. I can ſee his hat; but ſtill I look in vain to find out my poor father.

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: He will come, and I dare hope to ſee him very ſoon. The gentlemen muſt firſt have got out of the frozen valley, and they hide him from us. Doubtleſs it will not be long before we ſee him. Look again, my child.

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: I can ſee only the two gentlemen; my father is not with them.

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: And the gentlemen, do they ſeem waiting for him then? Have they their faces turned towards the place from which they come?

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: No; they walk ſtrait forward.

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: Then ſo much the better. If your father were not following them, or could not, they would hardly do ſo: they would try whatever they were able to aſſiſt him in his danger.

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: Yes, yes; we ſhould do as much; but they, on the other hand, ſeem rich; and I have often heard that ſuch deſpiſe the poor.

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: Not all; and then, too, they are men, and muſt be ſenſible of people's miſery like others. Would not you ſtretch forth a hand to help your little dog, were he in danger? Would you leave him unaſſiſited?

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: No indeed: but why? becauſe I love him: and do rich men love the poor? I have had money given me by one rich man to fight my play-mate.—Ah! I think I ſee my father now; yes, there he is! yes, yes, indeed; and, as you ſaid, behind the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I ſee him too. Thank God! But ſtill my heart beats grievouſly. I am in a tremble: So let us both ſit down; we will have our eyes fixed on them till they are ſafe on this ſide of the valley; and by that time, as I hope, my agitation will be calmed. Methinks they come on very quick. No doubt they wiſh to end their journey before day ſhuts in. Look, ſon: I fancy they are drawing nigh a precipice before them; and my fears again came on me.

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: It is a maſs of ice that forms a hollow underneath. It looks as if it were ſuſpended in the air, and they do not ſeem to know their danger; for they ſtop.

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: They ſtop! and may, perhaps, without expecting it, be ſwallowed up, or buried in the ruins, ſhould the ice fall down! It will fall down, and I ſhall ſee—oh heavens! fly for your life, my Julian! my dear Julian! fly! ſee what a maſs of ice may overwhelm you! Fly!—My voice, alas! at ſuch a diſtance, is not to be heard. My cries are uſeleſs. I am diſtracted!

sp.speaker: The Son.
sp.p: Mother, I can ſee no longer through the ſpying-glaſs, becauſe I cry; and yet I cannot take away my eyes. But now I ſee again. Yes, there they are, and they have cleared the precipice, quite cleared it. They are out of danger now: I ſee them: they turn back to view the rock under which they have paſſed, perhaps, without knowing at the time what peril they encountered. They lift their arms up; they are talking to each other; they are looking at ſome object that aſtounds them.

sp.speaker: The Mother.
sp.p: They are out of danger; that is enough for me. I ſee them: they have nothing now but level ground remaining. Kiſs me, my dear child! and let us both paſs on to meet your father. But at no time in my life ſhall I forget what I have felt this afternoon. Let us make all poſſible haſte, and beg that he would no more thus venture into danger. We ſhall have the little field, in that caſe, ſomewhat later; or it may be not at all; and it is no matter. We have lived till now without it: our enjoyments have not been on that account the leſs; we have in ſhort been happy, and what more can we deſire? I ſhall not for the future know that he is returning to thoſe frozen regions, without fearing every danger that I know, and ſuch as I can but gueſs. He may, perhaps, be ſafe feated at his eaſe beneath a tree; but I ſhall fancy that I behold him ſtruggling in a gap, and ſtriving to get out. Whatever money he receives from thoſe whom he may conduct,—if he but loves us, he ſhould think that he buys it at a price too dear.

div.p:
The mother and the ſon upon this went forward, and I followed them till they had gained the valley. They preſſed on to meet a huſband, and a father; and at laſt, when they obſerved him with the Engliſhmen draw near, they durſt not note him. They ſat down together, let
him paſs, and then got up and followed ſlowly after. It was not before they reached their cottage, that the wife and ſon ran both to Julian, and together ſunk into his arms. The ſon related every thing which they had both ſeen and feared. The mother did not ſpeak at firſt; but when ſhe ſaw her huſband touched by the affectionate behaviour of his ſon, ſhe once again embraced him and ſhed tears. He promiſed that he would never more affright her by returning to the ice, but cultivate his field in peace.

div.head: THE BREAKFAST.
div.p: COME, ſaid Mr. Glaſſington to Percival his ſon, one beauteous ſummer morning, here is a baſket with ſome cake and currants in it. Let us go and breakfaſt by the river's ſide.

With all my heart, papa, ſaid Percival, and jumped about for joy. He took the baſket in one hand, and with the other in his father's, haſtened towards the river. Having reached it, they walked on a little way to chuſe a proper place; when Mr. Glaſſington arriving at a very pleaſant ſpot, cried out, Let us ſtop here, Percival; for this methinks will yield us a delightful proſpect, while we ſit and eat.

sp.speaker: Percival.
sp.p: But how are we to eat without a table?

sp.speaker: Mr. Glaſſington.
sp.p: Fortunately, here is the trunk of an old tree, which would ſerve by way of table very well, if we had need of one; but you may eat your currants as they lie together in the baſket.

sp.speaker: Percival.
sp.p: So I can: but how ſhall we ſupply the want of chairs?

sp.speaker: Mr. Glaſſington.
sp.p: And do you reckon this ſoft graſs then nothing? See how thick it is ſet with flowers. We will take our ſeat upon it: or perhaps you would rather chuſe the carpet?

sp.speaker: Percival.
sp.p: Chuſe the carpet! Why you know, papa, the carpet is faſt nailed down upon the parlour floor.

sp.speaker: Mr. Glaſſington.
sp.p: It is true, there is a carpet there; but there is one here alſo.

sp.speaker: Percival.
sp.p: I do not ſee it, if there is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Glaſſington.
sp.p: Why, what is the graſs then, but a carpet for the fields? And what a charming one too! It is of a freſher colour, and much downier than any one that we have. Then how ſpacious! it covers every hill, and all the level plain. The lambs repoſe upon it at their eaſe. Think, Percival, what they would have to ſuffer, on a bare or ſtony piece of ground! Their limbs are ſo extremely delicate, they could not but be very quickly injured. They have mothers, but thoſe mothers cannot make them up ſoft feather-beds. God therefore has provided for them better than the poor ſheep can, and made them this ſoft couch, where they may roll about, or ſleep entirely at their eaſe.

sp.speaker: Percival.
sp.p: And then, papa, there is one good thing befides, that they may eat it when they like.

sp.speaker: Mr. Glaſſington.
sp.p: Oho! I underſtand your meaning: ſo here take your cake and currants.

sp.speaker: Percival,
sp.p: (biting off a bit.) Oh! how good! There is nothing wanting but a ſtory while I am eating. Will you tell me one, papa; the prettieſt that you know?

sp.speaker: Mr. Glaſſington.
sp.p: With all my heart. Your cake reminds me of a ſtory that I can tell about three cakes.

sp.speaker: Percival.
sp.p: One, two, three cakes! Oh, what a charming ſtory that muſt be! So quick, papa, and tell it me.

sp.speaker: Mr. Glaſſington.
sp.p: Come then firſt, and ſit beſide me. Be wholly at your eaſe, and then you will hear the better.

sp.speaker: Percival.
sp.p: I am quite ready; ſo begin, papa.

sp.speaker: Mr. Glaſſington.
sp.p:
THERE was a little boy named Henry, about your age. His parents had but lately fixed him at a boarding-ſchool. He was a ſpecial boy, for ever at his book, and happened once to get the higheſt place at exerciſes. His mama was told it. She could no how keep from dreaming of the pleaſure; and when morning came, ſhe got up early, ſent to ſpeak with the cook, and ſaid as follows: Cook, you are to make a cake for Henry, who yeſterday was very
good at ſchool. With all my heart, replied the cook, and ſet immediately about it. It was as big as—let me ſee,—as big as—as a hat when flapped. The cook had ſtuffed it with nice almonds, large Piſtachio nuts, and candied lemon-peel, and iced it over with a coat of ſugar, ſo that it was very ſmooth, and of a perfect white. The cake no ſooner was come home from baking, than the cook put on her things, and carried it to ſchool. When Henry firſt ſaw it, he jumped up and down like any Merry Andrew. He was not ſo patient as to wait 'till they could let him have a knife, but fell upon it tooth and nail.— He ate and ate 'till ſchool began, and after ſchool was over he ate again: at night too it was the ſame thing 'till bed-time. Nay, a little fellow that Henry had for a playmate, told me that he put the cake upon his bolſter when he went to bed, and waked and waked a dozen times, that he might take a bit. I cannot ſo eaſily believe this laſt particular; but then it is very true, at leaſt, that on the morrow, when the day was hardly broke, he ſet about his favourite buſineſs once again, continuing at it all the morning, and by noon had ate it up. The dinner bell now rung, but Henry, as one may fancy, had no ſtomach, and was vexed to ſee how heartily the other children ate.
