Paſcal was marched up the country, with his comrades, to the army: but his heart, embittered by the horror of his ſituation, was inſenſible of any thing like goodneſs. His abandoned courſe of life, the crimes that he was inceſſantly committing, and his numberleſs deſertions, frequently ſubjected him to puniſhment. He was determined, if he could, to quit theſe regions, watched his opportunity, and ſtealing on board a veſſel bound to England, hid himſelf below till it had ſailed; nor did he quit his hiding place, till the ſhip was a great way out to ſea: he then came ſorth, and being brought before the captain, promiſed to work his paſſage to England; which the captain in the end accepted, as the veſſel was in want of men.

What, in the interim, was become of his unhappy parents? They alas! ſtill lived, if people may be ſaid to live whoſe ſad days are ſpent in anguiſh and deſpair. The crimes which their ſon had committed, and with which the neighbourhood all around them rung, had forced them to renounce their place of habitation, and go down and live in Suſſex, in a ſolitary quarter near the ſea.

A ſhort time after they were ſettled here, the ſhip, in which Paſcal was, arrived on that very part of the coaſt where they had fixed their retirement. For while they were a little way out to ſea, Paſcal, a thorough graduate in vice, had conſpired with ten or twelve deſperate fellows
of the crew, to murder every one on board who would not join in their conſpiracy, and ſo obtain poſſeſſion of the ſhip. They executed their infernal purpoſe; and ſoon after running the veſſel aſhore, they hoiſted out their boat at night, that they might come on ſhore, and pillage the inhabitants.

That very night the unhappy Mr. Dawkins in his houſe was up, and watching by his wife's ſick bed. Her grief for Paſcal's wretched fortune had long preyed upon her conſtitution; and by this time, after having ſuffered grievouſly, ſhe felt the agonies of death upon her. In the intervals of her delirium, ſhe called out for Paſcal: Where, where are you, ſaid the dying mother? Come, that I may preſs you to my heart, and pardon you before I die. At this the door is ſuddenly burſt open, and ten villains ruſh into the dwelling. Paſcal, with a hatchet in his hand, was firſt, and led them on. The father comes to meet them with a candle; but before his ſon could recollect him—The remainder is too horrid to relate: ſuffice it, that Paſcal and his gang were apprehended on the ſpot, and ſuffered at the gallows.

Children, if when you have read this ſtory, you dare think of giving way to any vice whatſoever, tremble at the poſſibility of your becoming criminal by degrees, and ending like Paſcal with the crime of parricide!

div.head: CHARACTERS.
div.p: The SCENE is in the country, at the Counteſs's, and in two rooms which open to the garden.

sp.stage: Jenny, (reckening up the counters on a table.)
sp.p: IT is all loſt labour to ſtand counting thus. I cannot make more than ninety-four; and yet there ſhould be an hundred. Well, I think, there never was a houſe like ours for hare-brained children; for wherever they once put their foot, one may be ſure, they will jumble every thing together, if they do not loſe ſomething or another. I muſt look about for them in every corner of the chamber.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: You ſeem uneaſy, Jenny: What are you ſeeking?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip's beſt counters.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Do not you ſee them on the table?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Yes, my lady; but the number is not complete.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: That ſhould not be.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: That ſhould not be, indeed; and yet there are no leſs than half a dozen wanting. Were there not an hundred?

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Yes; you know it as well as I.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Well then, there are but ninety-four.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs,
sp.p: (after having counted them.) There are indeed no more; and yet laſt night the number was complete. I put them up myſelf, when we had finiſhed playing. But what cauſed you to come now, and count them up?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Becauſe, as I paſſed by the door, I ſaw that the children had been playing with them.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Yet I abſolutely ordered that they ſhould not be touched. They have ivory ones to play with: who could give them theſe?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Themſelves.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Themſelves! Where are they?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: In the garden, madam, with their little company.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Fetch Julia here.—But ſtay, have none been here but Julia and Auguſtus?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Yes, their friends: and who can tell—

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: What, Jenny! can you poſſibly ſuſpect—

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: I will anſwer for your children, pleaſe your ladyſhip, and likewiſe the three young Davenports, as if they were myſelf.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: And not the others?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: I do not know them well enough.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: What, Jenny, two ſuch children as the Hon. Mr. Oddly and his ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: If your ladyſhip thinks ſit, I'll call Miſs Julia in: but here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs,
sp.p: (to Julia coming in.) Who told you, miſs, to uſe my ſilver counters? Did not I forbid you to meddle with them?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: It was not my fault, mama.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: And whoſe then, pray?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p:
The Hon. Mr. Oddly's and his ſiſter's. I had got the ivory counters, when they aſked me if I meant to
play with them, as they never had ſuch at home, and muſt have better; upon which they opened all the drawers and cloſets till they met with theſe.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Why did not you mention that I would never let you uſe them?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Good! as if they would hear me! I believe they would have beat us, had we not ſurrendered them.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Upon my word! Theſe children, as it ſeems, are charmingly brought up!

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: You ſhould at leaſt have counted them when you left off playing.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: That was what I wiſhed to do. But after I had got to twenty-four or thereabouts, Mr. Oddly ſnatched them from me, put them up pell-mell, and dragged us out into the garden with him.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Do you know that ſix are miſſing?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sure, mama!

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: How! ſure! when I have told you! See now whether one can truſt you in the leaſt! You know, it was your duty to take care of them.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I was confounded, dear mama; theſe children are ſo miſchievous! I was obliged to have my eye continually on them, as I thought they would have broke your china. I was obliged frequently to follow them about the room: they may have flung the counters, then, into ſome corner or another.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Well, but I muſt have them found.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: I know but one way, madam. Were I you, I would turn the little maſter's pockets inſide out before they left the houſe.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Fie, Jenny! would you have me affront their parents?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh! I am ſure, mama, not one among them can have ſtolen the counters,

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: So I think; but children of their age may be a little giddy-headed. So go to them, Julia, and politely aſk if any one among them may not by miſtake have put them up into his pocket. Your commiſſion is a nice one, and requires a little management. Take care not to offend them, by inſinuating that you think any one of the company capable of taking them purpoſely.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I ſhall take care, mama.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Accuſe yourſelf of negligence, and tell them that I ſhall blame you, if they are not ſoon found.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I underſtand you.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: And bid Robert, as you paſs, come here.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I will, mama.

sp.speaker: Jenny,
sp.p: (who has been employed in looking round the room.) I will anſwer for it, they are not here: there is not a corner but I have ſearched.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: This ſhould not have happened in my houſe. I dread, yet long to know, by what means they are vaniſhed.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Here I am, my lady: what is your pleaſure?

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: To inform you, Robert, that I have loſt ſince yeſterday ſix counters.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Does your ladyſhip ſuſpect me of taking them?

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: God forbid! I am too well acquainted with your honeſty for that. But I ſuppoſe, if you had croſſed the room, you might have ſeen them on ſome chair or elſewhere.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Counters on a chair?

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: I know, that is not a proper place for counters; but the children have been playing where they were, and might have inconſiderately left them in ſome corner, and you ſeen them.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: No, my lady, I have not.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it, and do not know what method to purſue. They muſt have certainly been loſt ſince morning, as I counted them myſelf laſt night.—But look about.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Your ladyſhip has ſeen how I have been ſearching for them. Servants are but badly off, when any thing is loſt about a houſe. However honeſt they may be, they are conſtantly ſuſpected.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Very likely; but the honeſt ſervant will on this occaſion pardon me, if I include her in my ſearch of the diſhoneſt.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: You may firſt of all examine me, my lady. Rogues are conſtantly the firſt to be diſpleaſed when they are ſuſpected.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: God be thanked, I have no fear of that ſort! But it cannot be a matter of indifference to the honeſt ſervant, when a thief is in the houſe.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: But put yourſelf into my place; what would you do? Think, Robert.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Do, my lady?—A thought this moment ſtrikes me; and provided I have leave to put it into execution, I will engage to find the counters.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: But you muſt not think of giving any one occaſion to ſuppoſe himſelf ſuſpected.—What is your deſign?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I cannot at preſent tell your ladyſhip. A ſingle ſyllable might ſpoil the buſineſs. Do but bring together all the children in the adjoining room. I promiſe you, the thief, if there is any thief among them, ſhall betray himſelf.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: I cannot tell whether I ſhould let—

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: You can truſt me, madam. Be aſſured that no one but the guilty perſon ſhall have reaſon to complain; and him, I d • re believe, you would not wiſh to ſpare.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Well, Robert, as I know your prudence, I rely upon it.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Good! my lady. Therefore I will go and begin conjuring. Do not be afraid! it is quite ſimple.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: My lady—did not he ſay ſomething about conjuring? But that I know myſelf innocent, I ſhould be frightened out of my wits.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Peace, ſimpleton!

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: What now, Auguſtus? You ſeem big with ſomething or another! Have you brought the counters with you?

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: No, mama: I have only learned that ſix are loſt. My ſiſter told us ſo juſt this moment.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: And how was the intelligence received?

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: We were exceedingly ſurprized. The two Davenports particularly, and their ſiſter, want to come and plead their innocence before you.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Plead! they are the laſt that I ſhould ſuſpect of ſuch a deed. And the Hon. Mr. Oddly—

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: Oh! he is furious; and told Julia, that to look upon him as a thief, was but a bad reception.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Julia was not rude, I hope, in telling them my meſſage.

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: No, mama, quite otherwiſe. She ſpoke with great politeneſs.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Then pray why was Mr. Oddly angry? There was nothing perſonal in what your ſiſter ſaid.

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: I cannot well tell the reaſon; but Eliza drew him privately aſide: he would not condeſcend to hear her. He is determined to be gone: his hat is fortunately here; he will come and fetch it, and declares that he will not remain a minute in the houſe. He threatens to complain to his papa.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Poſitively he muſt not go. I will tell his lordſhip the whole affair myſelf, when he comes to take him home.

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: The reſt wiſh greatly for permiſſion to appear and juſtify themſelves before you.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: There is no need of that. I only wiſhed to know if they could give me any information of the counters. They are all of them too well brought up, that I ſhould venture to accuſe them of a theft. • ut I am well acquainted with the whims of children. They will ſee every thing, and finger every thing; and from a want of thought, might eaſily have put a thing into their pocket, without any criminal intention.

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: Certainly they might, mama; as I did, you remember, when I took my ſiſter's purſe up by miſtake, and would have carried it away.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: But ſoftly! here they are.—Go, Jenny, and enquire if Robert is preparing matters. (Jenny goes out.)

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: The Counteſs, Auguſtus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Well, how fares it with you all, my little friends? I am glad to ſee you here.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: Miſs Julia has juſt now informed us, that your ladyſhip has loſt ſix counters of the number with which unluckily we were playing. I am ſorry for it; but could never think that your ladyſhip would have ſuſpected any one of us of having taken them. At leaſt I can aſſure you for my ſiſter and myſelf, that we know nothing of them.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: God forbid that I ſhould ſuſpect ſuch wellbred children, as I look upon you all to be. Sure Julia did not tell you that I ſuppoſed you to have the counters?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: No, my lady; all that ſhe ſaid, was to enquire if we had brought them out through inattention, or to play a little longer with them in the garden.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Which you might very innocently have done. It is ſhe alone that I blame in the affair, becauſe ſhe did not let you have her counters.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: She deſigned, I think, to uſe them.

sp.speaker: Lucius.
sp.p: I would never dare to ſhew my face again, if I had taken ſo much as a pin.

sp.speaker: Sophia,
sp.p: (emptying her pockets.) See, my lady, I have nothing here: and there are no other pockets to my ſlip.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: My dear children, I have already told you that I am far from ſuſpecting any of you to have them, when you ſay that you have not. They are certainly of no great value; yet I cannot but confeſs, that their loſs affects me.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p:
Were they only worth a ſtraw, they are your ladyſhip's, and ſhould not now be miſſing. But you know, there are ſuch things as ſervants; and they
are not always very honeſt. It is not the firſt time that we have ſuſpected them at home.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But it is the firſt time that any thing of the kind has happened in our houſe, dear Mr. Oddly, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: I would anſwer for our ſervants, men and women.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: I have truſted them this long time; but if you, ſir, (to the Hon. Mr. Oddly,) have made any obſervations, I requeſt you to let me know them.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: O, no no!—But when we went into the garden, did not—what is her name—the houſemaid enter?

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Jenny! Oh! I do not fear her. Theſe ſix years paſt that I have had her, ſhe might eaſily have made away with things of value, had ſhe been diſhoneſt.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: Did not your old footman come in likewiſe? I do not like his looks; and ſhould not chuſe to meet him in a lane at night.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Fie, ſir! what makes you thus ſuſpect the honeſt Robert? He was my father-in-law's confidential ſervant, and has been much longer in the family than even I myſelf. If he could poſſibly turn pilferer, neither you nor I could know what living creature we might truſt.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: It is not unlikely then, but ſome one may have got into the room when we were gone.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: That is not at all unlikely; and I am going to enquire. Amuſe yourſelves till I come back.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: No, madam; after what has paſſed, I cannot ſtay longer here. Auguſtus, can you tell me where they have put my hat?

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: It is taken to be bruſhed; you will have it brought you.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: I muſt have it inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: But won't you ſtay a little for papa? You know, he means to come and fetch us.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: I cannot poſſibly let you go home on foot. You would have upwards of three miles to walk. Stay here till I return: I will not detain you long.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: Auguſtus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: I am very much aſtoniſhed that your mama ſhould have ſuch thoughts of us! We ſteal her counters!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Sir, ſhe never had ſuch a thought. She might have fancied that we had put them, without thought, into our pockets. I might as eaſily have taken them in this way, as yourſelf, or any other: but to ſteal! ſhe did not mention the word, or any like it.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: Had there been none here but tradeſmen's children, ſhe might well have entertained ſuſpicions: but ſhe ſhould make ſome difference now.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: You ſpeak of us, ſir, I can ſee: your looks inform me ſo. But let me tell you, in my turn, that it is one's manners and principles, and not birth, that makes one truly noble.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: How theſe tradeſmen talk about their manners! You are very happy that there are ſo few children hereabout, and that Auguſtus and myſelf are forced to make you our companions, or have no diverſion. Did you live in London, you would not have ſuch an honour, notwithſtanding your fine manners.

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: Speak, ſir, for yourſelf alone; for juſt as here, in London too, I ſhould be proud to entertain my little friends.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes, certainly. They give us, to the full, as good examples as ſuch whipper-ſhapper noblemen as you.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: This, brother, you have deſerved. Why attack them firſt?

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: And you, too, upon me? You think certainly as I do, though you will not confeſs it. Have you forgot mama's inſtruction on the ſubject of familiarity with thoſe beneath us? "Never mix with tradeſmen's children: in the lower ranks of life, you will always have low thoughts."

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: And can you poſſibly ſuſpect that my friends are capable of being thieves?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Did we approach the table?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: No: whereas we ſaw you take the counters, and look at them I ſuppoſe half a dozen times. (The Hon. Mr. Oddly attempts to ſtrike her. Auguſtus and Gabriel hold his hand.)

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: Softly! You will have to deal with me elſe.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: No, no, my friend. I thank you, but I can take care of my ſiſter. Let him even threaten her. I am not a bit more frightened at his ſize than his title.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: Oh! it is far beneath me to diſpute with traders.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Very well: I hope then it is beneath you likewiſe to attack a little girl.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: I ſhall not permit her to inſult me.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: She would certainly have done much better, had ſhe held her tongue.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: But being ſuch a child, ſhe might be pardoned: and particularly when ſhe ſpoke the truth.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: The truth? What do mean by that?

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: She ſaid, that you took the counters and looked at them: that is all. Did ſhe ſay any more? And this certainly was true.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: I ſhan't even condeſcend to anſwer.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: You cannot take a better reſolution, when you have nothing but ſuch anſwers for us.

div.head: SCENE X.
div.stage: Auguſtus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia, the Counteſs.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: What is the meaning of all this? I will not have any quarrels here!

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: My lady, I expect, you will do me juſtice on theſe little folks!

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Folks! folks! who are they? I am not accuſtomed to have ſuch as viſit here called ſo.

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: He is angry, ſince we were not in a humour to endure his airs.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: He thought he ſhould have had a company of dukes at leaſt for play-fellows.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: And imagines that we ſhould be ſuſpected of this theft, much rather than a nobleman.

sp.speaker: Lucius.
sp.p: As if we had not a character to keep, as well as he has!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Ay, and would have beat me, had not Gabriel taught him better.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Why, ſure! it is not poſſible!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: To ſay the truth, my brother is too haſty.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Vivacity becomes his age very well; but we ſhould not be proud, quarrelſome, or raſh. Oh! here is Robert.

div.head: SCENE XI.
div.stage: The Counteſs, Auguſtus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia, Robert (carrying a baſket covered with a napkin.)

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: There is no more to be ſaid, my lady. Every body in this houſe is innocent, as ſure as my name is Robert; but however, for the ſatisfaction of the company, I will introduce my cock, who, you muſt know beforehand, is a conjurer. (Putting down the baſket on the table.)

sp.speaker: Sophia,
sp.p: (jumping for joy.) O, a cock! a cock!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Yes, nothing more; for look you! (He lifts up a napkin in the baſket, ſo that Sophia and the reſt diſcern the creature's neck and creſt.) Juſt like others, ſaving that my cock has not his equal in the world for knowledge: why, he will tell me things which no other perſon poſſibly can know. If a ſingle ſtraw, and nothing elſe, is miſſing, I need only run and have a conſultation with him: he will be ſure to know who ſtole it.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: You can then find out our counters, can you?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Can I? Why laſt Chriſtmas, at the alehouſe, I had loſt my pipe; ſo what did I do, but away and fetched my cock, who let me know that the groom had got it: and I think, you recollect, he broke his leg about a fortnight after.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: He can talk then?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Yes, like other cocks: Cock, cock-a-doodle-doo. On which, I underſtand him juſt as if it were you that ſpoke to me.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yet you never told us this before.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Becauſe we never yet loſt any thing.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Well, now, a truce to all this converſation, and begin.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Not quite ſo faſt, my lady. I muſt perform my conjuring in the dark.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: A very eaſy matter. You need only cloſe the ſhutters.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I will go out and puſh them to.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: You are much too ſhort: you cannot reach them. Robert will do that himſelf.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Yes, madam. (He goes out.)

div.head: SCENE XII.
div.stage: The Counteſs, Auguſtus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia.

sp.speaker: Auguſtus,
sp.p: (with the reſt, excepting the Hon. Mr. Oddly, who appears embarraſſed, lifting up the napkin.) This ſame cock ſeems ſupernatural, I fancy. (Looking at him earneſtly.) How his eyes ſhine!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: And his comb, how red it looks! my patience! how it ſhakes upon his head!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Do you imagine, then, that it has ſo much knowledge as Robert ſays?

sp.speaker: Lucius.
sp.p: Papa has often told us, what we ought to think of ſuch ſtrange ſtories.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Robert is a cunning ſportſman, and I am ſure can make birds hold their tongue, much better with his fowling piece, than teach a cock to talk by virtue of his wand.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Who knows! my governeſs has told me many wond'rous things of conjuration, and all that.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: I wonder, ſiſter, you can liſten to ſuch ſtories!

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: I am glad you have theſe notions of the matter, and ſhould like to laugh at Robert for his folly. What ſimplicity! a cock diſcover thieves!

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly,
sp.p: (forcing a ſmile.) I fancy we ſhall have a deal of laughing very ſhortly. (The ſhutters are cloſed all at once.) But why put the ſhutters to? (with uneaſineſs) I do not love darkneſs.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: If the cock cannot ſee, he will never find the thief out.—Will he, pray, mama?

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Well aſked: for I cannot tell you.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: I ſhould like, if I knew how, to make him ſpeak. Come pretty little cock, ſay ſomething.—See how dark it is.—Look out a little.—He does not ſpeak a word!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: The reaſon is, I ſuppoſe, he will obey his maſter only. (Robert comes in again.)

div.head: SCENE XIII.
div.stage: The Counteſs, Auguſtus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia, Robert.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Well, you are ſatisfied now, Robert, ſince you have thus ſhut out the day-light?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Yes, my lady; every thing is as it ſhould be. And ſo now, let thoſe remain that have not ſtolen the counters, but if any one is guilty, let that one go out.—What all remain!

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: How cunning!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I ſee clearly then that I muſt employ my art. (He waves his wand, and draws a circle on the floor; pronouncing ſomething unintelligible.)

q.l: That's well! So now, my cock, take heed;
And tell us, who are rogues indeed.

sp.p: Come now my little gentlemen and ladies, and let every one of you in turn, lift up the napkin here, and with his right hand, do you ſee, ſtroke Chanticleer upon the back. You will hear his muſic, when the thief once puts his hand upon him: but do not lift the cloth too high; juſt high enough to let your hand paſs under it.

q.l: So now, my pretty cock, take heed;
And tell us who are rogues indeed.

sp.p: Well! what will none of you begin?

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: What, every one afraid? Why, one would think you all guilty, at this rate!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: I am the youngeſt, but I will ſet the example. (She lifts up the cloth, and ſtrokes the cock twice over in the baſket.) Do you ſee, the cock does not ſpeak. It is not I that have ſtolen the counters.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Very well. Stand now in this place, with your hand behind you.—Is it ſo?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Feel, feel.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: That is right. Now you, ſir. (To Auguſtus.)

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: Oh! I fear as little as Miſs Sophia.—There. —He has not ſpoke.—Muſt I too hold my hand behind me?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Certainly; and every one.—Come here, by this young lady.—Well, another.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I will go next.— (She ſtrokes him.) If he had ſaid a word, he would have been a ſtory-teller.—

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: By your brother here. Who is next?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: It is my turn now. (She ſtrokes him.) As mute as any mackerel.—Yet I ſtroked him four times over.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Are your right hands all behind you? Do not forget that part.

sp.speaker: Gabriel,
sp.p: (to the Hon. Mr. Oddly.) I will follow you.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: As if I would have to do with ſuch child's play!

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: You would not ſurely ſpoil our ſport. A little complaiſance, pray, Mr. Oddly.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: If that is all, I have no objection. — (He puts his hand under the cloth.) There.—I do not find he has ſpoke for me, though I have ſtroked him more than others.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Here, ſir, with the reſt; and keep your hand behind you.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: There are none now, but my brothers left, that have not ſtroked him. It is one of them!—Oh, no; I do not think ſo. (Gabriel and Lucius imitate the others; upon which, the children all burſt out a laughing.)

sp.speaker: Lucius.
sp.p: And where is the thief?—Why no where.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Robert, you ſhould ſend your cock to Norwood; he is not cunning enough: and all this while my counters are not found.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I muſt acknowledge, this confounds me.—For a little while, however, patience; and do not ſtir.—Stand ſtill, I ſay.—They are juſt like ſo much quick-ſilver!— My circle, as I think, muſt be imperfect. I will go fetch a candle, and examine. I pray your ladyſhip, let no one quit his place.

div.head: SCENE XIV.
div.stage: The Counteſs, Auguſtus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: I knew before-hand, how all this would end.—Stupid nonſenſe!

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Why, this cock is no wiſer than his maſter.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Truly, I am glad to ſee him caught.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: And what does he deſign to do, when he has brought a light?

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: He will ſhew us.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: I ſhould like to ſee the cock now.—He will ſcarce hold his head up, I ſuppoſe, for ſhame.

div.head: SCENE XV.
div.stage: The Counteſs, Auguſtus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia, Robert.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: (returning with a light, and going up to Sophia.) Come, let me ſee your little hand. (She holds him out the left.) Not this,—but that behind you. Good!

sp.speaker: Sophia,
sp.p: (looking at her hand, and crying out.) Oh, what a hand I have! as black as any coal! And will it always be ſo?

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: Do not be frightened, little miſs! I will ſpeak about it to my cock, and you ſhall have both hands as white as ſnow.— (The children have not patience, but look all together at their hands, and inſtantly cry out at once.)

sp.speaker: Auguſtus.
sp.p: How black my ſingers are too!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: And mine likewiſe! What does Robert mean by this?

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: I would twiſt the creature's neck off, if I had him.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Fegs! my wriſtbands are come in a little for it!

sp.speaker: Lucius.
sp.p: It is as if my hand were painted!

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly,
sp.p: (lifting up his hand in triumph.) But ſee mine! There is none of the company that has a hand fit to look at, except me.

sp.speaker: Robert,
sp.p: (taking hold of the Hon. Mr. Oddly by the collar.) Very likely! Then, ſir, you have ſtole the counters.— Give them up, young gentleman, this inſtant, or I will ſearch your pockets, and then blacken you all over!

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Blacken him? O, brother! if you have got the counters, give them up this moment.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Take care, Robert, what you ſay!

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I am ſure, he has them. So, quit the counters, or expect to have a countenance as grimy as the blackeſt negro's.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly,
sp.p: (turning pale and trembling.) Is it poſſible that I ſhould have put them in my pocket, and not thought of what I was about? (He feels about him.) I recollect, indeed, I had them in my hand. (He ſeems ſurprized at finding them thruſt down into a corner of his waiſtcoat pocket.) Dear me! they are here indeed! Who would have thought it? (All the children look at one another with ſurpriſe, while the Hon. Mr. Oddly ſtands confounded.)

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Robert! (he approaches) take away your cock and candle, and go open us the ſhutters. Take care (in a whiſper) not to tell your fellow-ſervants how you found the counters. Say that they were thruſt a great way back into the table-drawer.

sp.speaker: Robert.
sp.p: I will, my lady. (He goes out.)

div.head: SCENE XVI.
div.stage: The Counteſs, Auguſtus, Julia, the Hon. Mr. Oddly, Eliza, Gabricl, Lucius, Sophia.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs
sp.p: Go, my little friends, into the other room: you will find water there to waſh your hands. Take care, and do not ſplaſh one another's clothes.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: No, no:—but if this black ſhould not come off?

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: It is nothing but a little ivory black, and water will remove it. You, ſir, (to the Hon. Mr. Oddly,) as your hands are clean, may ſtay with me.

div.head: SCENE XVII.
div.stage: The Counteſs, the Hon. Mr. Oddly.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Well then, my haughty little gentleman! and is it poſſible you could be guilty of ſo ſcandalous an action? You, that ſcarce a quarter of an hour ago looked down wi • h ſo much ſoorn upon the children of a reputable worthy tradeſman, and ſuppoſed your quality diſgraced by being in their company. They have at preſent their reverge, ſince they may call you, and with juſtice, a vile thief!

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: Pray pardon me, my lady!—I was playing with the counters—and without conſidering at the moment, muſt have put them into my pocket.—I have no other method of accounting for their being found upon me.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Pitiful excuſe! that aggravates your fault! At ſuch a tender age as yours, could I have poſſibly imagined one with ſo much front?

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: Believe me, madam, I had certainly no had deſign!—I took them without meaning ſo to do, and afterwards concealed the matter, from my crend of being taken for a thief.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: But after I had bid my daughter make enquiry for them with ſuch delicacy, you might eaſily have ſeemed to ſearch your peckets, and reſtored them without bluſhing. Your proceeding would have then been looked up was nothing but an inadvertoncy.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: I did not think of that, my lady.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: What then did you think, when you durſt drop hints that poſſibly my honeſt ſervants might have taken them? or that my children's little friends were objects of ſuſpicion? What were your ideas, when you made believe to ſt •• ke the cock?

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: But, madam, I did ſtroke him.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p:
Hold your tongue, you little raſcal!— for that 〈◊〉 is not too bad for your deſervings. Happlly, as yet, you have not got ſufficient cunning to conceal your wicked actions. You did ſtroke the cock! Is that then your aſſertion? Do not you ſee, that if you had, you would have blacked your hands as well as all the others,
Robert having ſmeared him over with a certain compoſition? Your companions were not in the leaſt afraid to ſtroke him, as their conſcience did not any way reproach them for the theft; but as for you, the apprehenſion leſt the ſervant's artifice might really be conju • ation awed you, and the means that you choſe to avoid detection have betrayed you. Oh! how politic you thought yourſelf, I warrant, in pretending only, as you did, to ſtroke the cock; but honeſty you would have found much better policy. You deſerve that I ſhould tell my lord, your father, of your laudable behaviour, when he comes to fetch you.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly,
sp.p: (falling on his knees.) Oh, no! Pray, my lady, I beſeech you! He would beat me: he would tread me under foot.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: And it would be better that he ſhould do ſo, than bring up a monſter to diſgrace him at ſome future period; for of what hereafter will you not be capable, ſince in the ſeaſon of your infancy, as I may call it, you can perpetrate ſo great a crime?

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: Ah! madam, pardon me for pity's ſake, and never—

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Doubtleſs you have often made theſe promiſes to others; for this hardly is your firſt tranſgreſſion. Every circumſtance confirms it. So much falſity and impudence—

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: Then hear me, my good lady! If you ever heat, in future, that I make free with any thing whatſoever that is not mine—

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Inform me, in the firſt place, what did you intend to do with theſe ſix counters? You could hardly think that you would have any opportunity of uſing them, but they muſt inſtantly be known. You meant to ſell them, then, for money?

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: No, believe me! I was pleaſed with looking at them. I ſuppoſed that no one would remember having ſeen them elſewhere, and on that account ſecreted them, my lady.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: And how could you deſire to have another's property? Confeſs! Is this your firſt offence?

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly,
sp.p:
(hiding his face.) No, no indeed, my lady. I have often been a thief at home; but never
having been ſuſpected there, I hoped to have the ſame good fortune here.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: A very wicked ſort of reaſoning this! For, granting that no one upon earth ſuſpected you, do not you know that God ſees and puniſhes whatever people do amiſs? Perhaps, however, this event is for your benefit; and you will prove more likely to amend, when you have once been puniſhed as you merit.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: Let it be by you, my lady, or by any one, but not by my papa. Let him know nothing of the matter, I conjure you. Tell it, if you pleaſe, to my mama, but keep the matter from his knowledge.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: There again! You would not have your father know it, as you fear the blows that he might beſtow upon you. Thus, it is nothing but an abjectneſs that guides you, even in the work of your repentance; and it is not for his peace of mind that you would conceal it from him, for you are not afraid leſt your mama ſhould know it, becauſe ſhe would not beat you. It is not your idea to conſult her peace of mind.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: Then tell it my preceptor.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: I am ſenſible, indeed, how much the knowledge of your fault would mortally afflict your parents, and from that conſideration, not upon your own account, conſent to ſpare you; but on this condition, that you come with your preceptor hither, and before him let me have your ſolemn promiſe of amendment. I will requeſt him to keep watch upon your conduct; but if ever you ſhould break your word, I will not only mention this adventure of the counters to his lordſhip, but let every body elſe know it.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: I conſent you ſhould do ſo, my lady.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: You might think that, after this, I ſhould forbid your keeping company with Julia and Auguſtus; but I have at heart your reformation, and will judge thereof myſelf. You may continue therefore coming here.

sp.speaker: The Hon. Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: But how ſhall I dare to face your ſervants?

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p:
You have nothing to fear upon that account, for I have had more care and forethought for your reputation than yourſelf, by telling Robert not to ſpeak about it in the kitchen; and to hide your lie, have been
compelled to one myſelf, that they might not ſuppoſe you guilty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: Ah! my lady, how much am I indebted to your bounty! I ſhall never forget the ſervice that you have done me. But your children?—and the little company now with them?

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: I am well acquainted with their goodneſs, and am ſure that they will forgive you. Call them. (Mr. Oddly, with a downcaſt look, goes ſlowly towards the door, and bids them enter.)

div.head: SCENE XVIII.
div.stage: The Counteſs, Mr. Oddly, Auguſtus, Julia, Eliza, Gabriel, Lucius, Sophia.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: Go, ſir, you are a diſgrace to me; I will never call you brother again.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: No, my dear Eliza, he is not ſo guilty as you think him. He has told me every thing. It was to play a little with the counters out of doors that he took them; but when once the matter ſeemed conſidered as a theft, he was terrified at the idea of incurring my ſuſpicion. This apparent guilt has ſprung from a miſtaken ſhame, which I am very willing to excuſe; but not (looking at the little Davenports) his ſcandalous endeavours to make you, my little dears, ſeem guilty.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: Oh! my lady, we do not wiſh him any harm at preſent for it, as we know that we ſhould forgive even ſuch as wrong us, and particularly when we ſee them unhappy.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: Do you mark that, Mr. Oddly? Such a conduct ought to ſhew you how much nobler it is to have an elevated way of thinking, than to boaſt an elevated birth. You find yourſelf entirely at the mercy even of thoſe whom you have inſulted; and, with all the boaſt of your nobility, you are the object of their pity.

sp.speaker: Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: Oh, what ſhame! but I ſubmit to undergo it.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: We will never introduce again the mention of this matter. It ſhall be a ſecret for the time to come between us; ſhan't it, brother?

sp.speaker: Lucius.
sp.p: Yes, he may rely upon my ſilence.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: And you, ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: I will not have him beat. I know what pain it gives one, (Mr. Oddly in the tranſports of his gratitude embraces them.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: I deſire, but dare not aſk, to be acquainted with you for the future.

sp.speaker: Gabriel.
sp.p: It will be doing us an honour, if you will ſtill continue upon terms of friendſhip with us.

sp.speaker: Auguſtus and Julia.
sp.p: And for our part, we ſhall be no leſs delighted with your company, as long as you regard our friends.

sp.speaker: Eliza.
sp.p: You are all of you too good. He does not merit ſuch indulgence, and papa muſt be informed of every thing.

sp.speaker: The Counteſs.
sp.p: You will loſe my friendſhip and eſteem entirely, I muſt tell you, Miſs Eliza, could you poſſibly be unaffected with your brother's laudable repentance, when even ſtrangers overlook his error. Do not employ the advantage that his offence affords you, to undo him in his parents' good opinion; but, for the future, let your counſel ſhew him how to act, that he may merit their affection. I dare anſwer, you need never be aſhamed of any action of his hereafter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Oddly.
sp.p: I ſhould be unworthy of ſuch bounty, if this leſſon could be blotted out from my remembrance.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Take due care it be not, or Beware of the conjuring Bird.
